columns.text:
In this exercise, we'll analyze an important characteristic of companies called price to stock ratio.

**Let's get started!**

The price-to-sales (PS) ratio is a benchmark that compares a company's stock price to its income from sales. It is the value financial markets assign to each dollar of a company's sales or revenues.

We can calculate the price-to-sales ratio by dividing the stock price by sales per share:

$$\text{PS} = \dfrac{\text{Price}}{\text{Sales per share}} \tag{1}$$

By comparing PS ratios to those of similar companies, investors and analysts can determine how much they are willing to pay per dollar of sales of a company's shares. It may also be used to compare a business against its prior performance.

The main drawback of PS ratios is that they do not consider whether the business has earned or will earn earnings in the future. Also, comparing companies in different industries can be problematic.

We are given the following information:

1. The number of available shares is 130,000
2. The sales are \$2.1 million
2. The benchmark PS is 4.3

First, we'll calculate the sales per share:

$$\text{Sales per share} = \dfrac{\$21,000,000}{130,000} = \$16.15384615

Now, by inputting all the values into Eq.$(1)$ we can solve for the appropriate price:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PS} &= \dfrac{\text{Price}}{\text{Sales per share}} \\[15pt]
\text{Price}&= \text{PE} \times \text{Sales per share} \\[15pt]
\text{}&= 4.3 \times \$16.15384615
 \\[15pt]
&= \$69.46153845
\end{aligned}$$

If benchmark PE was 21, the stock price would be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&= \text{PS} \times \text{Sales per share} \\[15pt]
\text{}&= 3.6 \times \$16.15384615 \\[15pt]
&= \$58.15384614
\end{aligned}$$

**Let's recap what we have done in this exercise!**

First, we explained the fundamental concept of this exercise - the PS benchmark. We have discussed its definition and where it's commonly used (and for what purpose).

Finally, we used the PS benchmark formula to find the correct stock price.
